Victims & Attack Patterns

üë• The People Behind the Patterns

Humanitarian workers go where others can‚Äôt ‚Äî into war zones, disaster areas, and refugee camps.
But when violence erupts, who pays the highest price?

This section follows a scroll-driven path through the human cost of aid work.
As you move down, let the data guide the story ‚Äî one chart, one insight at a time.

üßë‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è Nationals Bear the Brunt

First, let‚Äôs look at who is being harmed.

National staff ‚Äî not international expats ‚Äî suffer the vast majority of attacks.
They‚Äôre the ones who stay after the cameras leave.

This raises a critical question:
Are we doing enough to protect those closest to the danger?

ü©∏ What Kind of Harm?

Next: What happens to those who are targeted?

Most are wounded, but thousands have been killed or kidnapped.
These are not isolated cases ‚Äî they‚Äôre systemic outcomes of conflict and disregard.

üî• Do Some Attacks Hurt More?

Not all attacks lead to the same outcomes. Some are deadlier than others.

This chart shows the harsh truth:

  • Shootings are the most lethal.
  • Kidnappings cause fewer deaths, but more psychological trauma.
  • Aerial attacks and IEDs often wound in high numbers ‚Äî especially in urban areas.

Aid agencies can use this data to match their response protocols to real-world risk.

üéØ What It All Means

We now know:

  • Who gets hurt: Mostly national staff
  • How they‚Äôre harmed: Killed, kidnapped, and wounded in large numbers
  • By what: A range of violent tactics, some more deadly than others

This isn‚Äôt just tragedy. It‚Äôs a call to act wisely and plan better.
